title: Assignment 2
text:
The above image shows the comparison of Trump and Kamala over the last 90 days as seen on google trends website. As we can see that there is a spike in Trump’s popularity because of the assination attempt on him. Otherwise, both the leaders are pretty neck to neck in competition.
We can perform the same operations using R code as shown below:
The below R code does the same operations as the google trends website but the difference is that it is being done using code and in the website we need to enter the operations such as entering number days of past data, importing in CSV format, entering names of leaders manually. Here we pass all these operations in R code manually to get similar results shown below

# EPPS 6302: Google Trends data 
# Sample program for using gtrendsR for collecting Google Trends data
# Documentation: vignette("quickstart", package = "gtrendsR")
# Website: https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/gtrendsR/index.html
# GitHub: https://github.com/PMassicotte/gtrendsR


## Load library and run gtrends
library(gtrendsR)
HarrisTrumpElection = gtrends(c("Trump","Harris","election"), time = "all")

## Select data for plotting
HarrisTrumpElection_interest <- HarrisTrumpElection$interest_over_time

## Plot data
par(family="Georgia")
plot(HarrisTrumpElection_interest$hits, type="l")

Warning in xy.coords(x, y, xlabel, ylabel, log): NAs introduced by coercion








## Try another dataset?
#borderimg = gtrends("border immigrant", time = "all")

## Collect data by timeframe

gtrends(c("Harris", "Trump"), time = "now 1-H") # last hour

title: Tufte BlogPost
text:
In this engaging and exciting video by Dr. Tufte, he explains how data can be used to convey a story, which can be engaging and misleading at the same time. Dr. Tufte clears the misconception about the term “data,” where most people assume that data is something concrete, however, myriad, stories can be told using data.
Dr. Tufte’s discussion on the significance of data visualization is brought to life through compelling examples. From Galileo’s map to a music graph that dynamically captures every note and rhythm, these instances underscore the potent role of data visualization in data mapping.
He then transitions by stating that “brilliance is rare” and discussing why most research findings are false. These findings involve data that can be manipulated in any way the authors want the results to be. He then discusses the Phillip curve and functional MRI examples, where false positives are generated using a salmon. Furthermore, he also discusses the “Google flu of overfitting.” where you “torture the data long enough, it will tell you anything.”
Using these examples, the author then moves on to a more philosophical question of whether data is being used to reach the truth. He emphasizes the need for more exploratory studies rather than confirmatory studies, and the importance of data forensics. This attitude of ‘sampling to please’ needs to stop, and we cannot expect people to keep their own scores. He finally urges people to look at the real world and not representations. Finally, he then discusses the survival bias using the example of castles.
This was an eye-opening presentation by Dr. Tufte on how data can be weaponized for the purpose you want to achieve. Thus, it is important to use data to find the truth and for a noble cause. After this presentation, I will make sure that I will use data to get closer to reality. This presentation has also made me realize to view data critically and not believe the results of any paper blindly, so I will now question the results of papers and the graphs used in these papers.
Furthermore, I will also question researchers on their findings and only accept results after thoroughly investigating the data sources and the methods used for data representation. This video has made me more aware of how I should read data and write and interpret my own reports generated from the data that I have used.
From a practical standpoint, I will use data from suitable sources and not make any unnecessary assumptions about data. I will also be cautious about my surveys, making sure they are not biased in any way. I will use random sampling, which was discussed in class before, and will ask questions that the respondents are comfortable replying to. Therefore, this video has been an eyeopener for me and I will practically try to implement all that Dr. Tufte has highlighted in his video.

title: Welcome
text:
I am a Ph.D. candidate in Public Policy and Political Economy at The University of Texas at Dallas and have completed my MBA in Finance from Penn State University. Furthermore, I am a CFA charter holder who passed all levels (Levels 1, 2 & 3) of the prestigious CFA® program. I learned about software development, web design, databases, programming, and computer networks and systems in my bachelor’s program in Information Technology. After my bachelor’s, I joined TCS, India’s top IT company, as an engineer.
My early and repeated success in managing my family’s stock portfolio not only strengthened my interest in finance but also ignited a passion that has been driving me ever since. This passion led me to pursue an MBA in Finance from Penn State University, where I also received a one-year scholarship. After my MBA, I joined Oracle Inc., America’s leading tech firm. However, my passion for finance still burned bright, and I was determined to gain real-world experience in the field of finance.
Thus, I joined a start-up in India as an equity research analyst, where I researched different stocks, sectors, the economy, geopolitics, and international relations. Furthermore, I also executed risky trades, such as leveraged long/short positions using derivatives such as futures and options with little handholding. I was then offered the position of portfolio manager, where I managed a portfolio of stocks worth $1 million.
As a portfolio manager, I realized that the financial performance of many companies was a function of relations between state and central governments and foreign policy. Thus, I decided to pursue a Ph.D. in Public Policy and Political Economy, which strengthened my understanding of International Relations and the functioning of Governments. Currently, my research focuses on studying municipal bonds in different countries, where I study the impact of political risk on municipal bond yields/spreads.
As someone with a blend of academic and professional experience in India and the USA, I have worked across the Finance and Tech sectors, gaining a global perspective and adaptability. Therefore, having worked in both parts of the world and having interacted with people from different nationalities, I have a rich repertoire of academic acquisitions and a practical understanding of the private sector and the government.

# Chart 2
  
  # Chatgpt was used to assist with the coding
  # Load necessary libraries
  library(ggplot2)
  library(gridExtra)
  
  # Reshape the Anscombe data for ggplot2 (long format)
  anscombe_long <- data.frame(
    x = c(anscombe$x1, anscombe$x2, anscombe$x3, anscombe$x4),
    y = c(anscombe$y1, anscombe$y2, anscombe$y3, anscombe$y4),
    group = rep(c("Set 1", "Set 2", "Set 3", "Set 4"), each = nrow(anscombe))
  )
  
  # Create a new plotting function for bar charts
  gg_anscombe_bar <- function(data, group_label) {
    ggplot(data, aes(x = as.factor(x), y = y)) +  # Convert x to factor for bar chart
      geom_bar(stat = "identity", aes(fill = group_label), color = "black") +  # Create bars
      labs(title = paste("Bar Chart: ", group_label), x = "x", y = "Sum of y") +
      theme_minimal(base_family = "serif") +  # Set font to serif
      theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, size = 14))  # Center the title
  }
  
  # Bar Plot 1
  bp1 <- gg_anscombe_bar(anscombe_long[anscombe_long$group == "Set 1", ], "Set 1") +
    scale_fill_manual(values = "red")
  
  # Bar Plot 2
  bp2 <- gg_anscombe_bar(anscombe_long[anscombe_long$group == "Set 2", ], "Set 2") +
    scale_fill_manual(values = "darkgreen")
  
  # Bar Plot 3
  bp3 <- gg_anscombe_bar(anscombe_long[anscombe_long$group == "Set 3", ], "Set 3") +
    scale_fill_manual(values = "orange")
  
  # Bar Plot 4
  bp4 <- gg_anscombe_bar(anscombe_long[anscombe_long$group == "Set 4", ], "Set 4") +
    scale_fill_manual(values = "blue")
  
  # Arrange the four bar charts into a grid
  grid.arrange(bp1, bp2, bp3, bp4, nrow = 2)







# Chart 3

  library(ggplot2)
  
  # Summarize the dataset
  # We'll use 'mtcars' dataset and create a bar chart of car models vs their horsepower (hp)
  data <- mtcars
  data$car_model <- rownames(data)
  
  # Create a horizontal bar chart
  ggplot(data, aes(x = hp, y = reorder(car_model, hp))) +
    geom_bar(stat = "identity", fill = "lightcoral") +
    labs(title = "Horsepower of Car Models in mtcars Dataset",
         x = "Horsepower (hp)", y = "Car Models") +
    theme_minimal()







  # Citation: This code was generated using ChatGPT.
  
# Chart 4
  
  data <- mtcars
  data$transmission <- ifelse(data$am == 0, 'Automatic', 'Manual')
  
  # Summarize data: Average mpg by number of cylinders and transmission type
  data_summary <- aggregate(mpg ~ cyl + transmission, data, mean)
  
  # Create a grouped column chart
  ggplot(data_summary, aes(x = factor(cyl), y = mpg, fill = transmission)) +
    geom_bar(position = "dodge", stat = "identity") +
    labs(title = "Average MPG by Cylinder and Transmission Type (mtcars Dataset)", 
         x = "Number of Cylinders", y = "Miles per Gallon (MPG)") +
    theme_minimal() +
    scale_fill_manual(values = c("Automatic" = "lightblue", "Manual" = "lightcoral"))

title: Data Visualization Assignment 2
text:
Scatterplot

par(mfrow=c(3, 2))
x <- c(0.5, 2, 4, 8, 12, 16) 
y1 <- c(1, 1.3, 1.9, 3.4, 3.9, 4.8) 
y2 <- c(4, .8, .5, .45, .4, .3)

# Setting label orientation, margins c(bottom, left, top, right) & text size
par(las=1, mar=c(4, 4, 2, 4), cex=.7) 
plot.new()
plot.window(range(x), c(0, 6))
lines(x, y1)
lines(x, y2)
points(x, y1, pch=16, cex=2) # Try different cex value?  
points(x, y2, pch=21, bg="white", cex=2)  # Different background color
par(col="gray50", fg="gray50", col.axis="gray50")
axis(1, at=seq(0, 16, 4)) # What is the first number standing for?
axis(2, at=seq(0, 6, 2))
axis(4, at=seq(0, 6, 2))
box(bty="u")
mtext("Travel Time (s)", side=1, line=2, cex=0.8)
mtext("Responses per Travel", side=2, line=2, las=0, cex=0.8)
mtext("Responses per Second", side=4, line=2, las=0, cex=0.8)
text(4, 5, "Bird 131")
par(mar=c(5.1, 4.1, 4.1, 2.1), col="black", fg="black", col.axis="black")

3D Plot

# Persp
x <- seq(-10, 10, length= 30)
y <- x
f <- function(x,y) { r <- sqrt(x^2+y^2); 10 * sin(r)/r }
z <- outer(x, y, f)
z[is.na(z)] <- 1
# 0.5 to include z axis label
par(mar=c(0, 0.5, 0, 0), lwd=0.5)
persp(x, y, z, theta = 30, phi = 30, 
      expand = 0.5)







par(mar=c(5.1, 4.1, 4.1, 2.1), lwd=1)

title: Assignment 5
text:
Customizing using R Graphics

# Sample data for demonstration
set.seed(123)
data <- rnorm(100, mean = 50, sd = 10)
categories <- factor(sample(letters[1:5], 100, replace = TRUE))
x <- rnorm(100)
y <- x + rnorm(100, sd = 0.5)

# Custom theme setup
my_theme <- function() {
  par(col.axis="blue", col.lab="darkgreen", col.main="purple", col.sub="darkred",
      lwd=2, cex.main=1.5, cex.lab=1.2, cex.axis=1.1)
}

# 1. Histogram
my_theme()
hist(data, main = "Customized Histogram", xlab = "Values", ylab = "Frequency", col = "skyblue", border = "darkblue")
text(x = 70, y = 15, labels = "Source: Customized by ChatGPT", col = "red")







# 2. Vertical Bar Chart
my_theme()
barplot(table(categories), main = "Customized Vertical Bar Chart", xlab = "Categories", ylab = "Frequency", col = "coral")
text(x = 3, y = 20, labels = "Source: Customized by ChatGPT", col = "red")







# 3. Horizontal Bar Chart
my_theme()
barplot(table(categories), main = "Customized Horizontal Bar Chart", xlab = "Frequency", ylab = "Categories", col = "lightgreen", horiz = TRUE)
text(x = 20, y = 3, labels = "Source: Customized by ChatGPT", col = "red")







# 4. Pie Chart
my_theme()
pie(table(categories), main = "Customized Pie Chart", col = rainbow(5), labels = paste(names(table(categories)), ": ", table(categories), sep=""))
mtext("Source: Customized by ChatGPT", side = 1, line = 3, col = "red")







# 5. Boxplot
my_theme()
boxplot(data, main = "Customized Boxplot", xlab = "Data", ylab = "Values", col = "pink", border = "purple")
text(x = 1.2, y = 70, labels = "Source: Customized by ChatGPT", col = "red")







# 6. Scatterplot
my_theme()
plot(x, y, main = "Customized Scatterplot", xlab = "X values", ylab = "Y values", pch = 19, col = "orange", cex = 1.5)
text(x = 1.5, y = 3, labels = "Source: Customized by ChatGPT", col = "red")










Customizing using ggplot2

# Install ggplot2 if not already installed
# install.packages("ggplot2")

# Load the package
library(ggplot2)

# Custom theme function for ggplot2
my_custom_theme <- theme(
  plot.title = element_text(color = "purple", size = 16, face = "bold"),
  axis.title = element_text(color = "darkgreen", size = 14),
  axis.text = element_text(color = "blue", size = 12),
  legend.title = element_text(color = "darkred", size = 12),
  legend.text = element_text(color = "blue"),
  plot.caption = element_text(color = "red", face = "italic")
)
# Sample data
set.seed(123)
data <- rnorm(100, mean = 50, sd = 10)

# Histogram
ggplot(data.frame(data), aes(x = data)) +
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 5, fill = "skyblue", color = "darkblue") +
  labs(title = "Customized Histogram", x = "Values", y = "Frequency", caption = "Source: Customized by ChatGPT") +
  my_custom_theme







# Sample categorical data
categories <- factor(sample(letters[1:5], 100, replace = TRUE))

# Vertical Bar Chart
ggplot(data.frame(categories), aes(x = categories)) +
  geom_bar(fill = "coral", color = "black") +
  labs(title = "Customized Vertical Bar Chart", x = "Categories", y = "Frequency", caption = "Source: Customized by ChatGPT") +
  my_custom_theme







# Horizontal Bar Chart
ggplot(data.frame(categories), aes(x = categories)) +
  geom_bar(fill = "lightgreen", color = "black") +
  coord_flip() +  # Flip to horizontal
  labs(title = "Customized Horizontal Bar Chart", x = "Frequency", y = "Categories", caption = "Source: Customized by ChatGPT") +
  my_custom_theme







# Pie Chart data
pie_data <- as.data.frame(table(categories))

# Boxplot
ggplot(data.frame(data), aes(x = "", y = data)) +
  geom_boxplot(fill = "pink", color = "purple") +
  labs(title = "Customized Boxplot", x = "Data", y = "Values", caption = "Source: Customized by ChatGPT") +
  my_custom_theme







# Scatterplot data
x <- rnorm(100)
y <- x + rnorm(100, sd = 0.5)

# Scatterplot
ggplot(data.frame(x, y), aes(x = x, y = y)) +
  geom_point(color = "orange", size = 3) +
  labs(title = "Customized Scatterplot", x = "X Values", y = "Y Values", caption = "Source: Customized by ChatGPT") +
  my_custom_theme







# Pie Chart data
pie_data <- as.data.frame(table(categories))

# Pie Chart

# Sample categorical data
categories <- factor(sample(letters[1:5], 100, replace = TRUE))
pie_data <- as.data.frame(table(categories))

# Create the pie chart
ggplot(pie_data, aes(x = "", y = Freq, fill = categories)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", width = 1) +        # Create the bar chart base
  coord_polar(theta = "y") +                      # Transform it into a pie chart
  labs(title = "Customized Pie Chart", fill = "Categories", caption = "Source: Customized by ChatGPT") +
  my_custom_theme +
  theme_void() +                                  # Remove axes and gridlines
  theme(axis.text = element_blank(),              # Hide axis text
        axis.ticks = element_blank(),             # Hide axis ticks
        panel.grid = element_blank())             # Hide grid lines

title: Data Visualization Assignment 1
text:
Critique of the Graph

This graph shows us the returns to education versus cost of education over time. As per the graph, we see that the returns to education have remained constant over time while the costs have increased. Thus, the graphs suggests that there is not much to gain in terms of money when it comes to education.
The graph has several inconsistencies, the graph shows income of only the first year after a student graduates, however the income of the student may increase after the first year depending on the individual performance where his/her education may come handy.
Moreover, this is highly aggregated data where the student income of different majors is being averaged. For example, some majors may be paid more while other majors may be paid less depending on market demand. Furthermore, this graph does not take into account different business cycles/economic cycles.
The graph also does not specify the demographics for example, is the graph talking about students who are citizens or students who are international. Furthermore, the students are also not categorized based on the racial and ethnic grounds to get a better understanding of what is happening with earnings as the students graduate. Moreover, many students may also choose to take a break after they graduate, to get a better job which might again skew averages.
Thus, we can get a better picture only after answering these questions satisfactorily.

title: Comparison of Data Visualization Styles of Dr. Tufte and Wickham
text:
In this blog post, I will compare two authors, Dr.Tufte and Mr.Wickham. Dr. Tufte has a philosophical style of data visualization. He likes people to ponder the data generation processes, how the data is collected, and whether the data collection can lead to the truth. He discussed several examples in the field of medicine where false results may end the lives of so many people. He also discusses surveys and the importance of an appropriate sample. So, surveys should be done carefully to obtain the right results. “Torture the dataset until it gives in.” he uses this phrase to demonstrate the example of data collection. He then discusses the Phillip curve and the example of Salmon to make us understand the importance of false positives.
Dr. Tufte’s presentation was a powerful reminder of how data can be weaponized for any purpose. It underscored the importance of using data to uncover the truth and for noble causes. This insight has inspired me to use data more responsibly, ensuring that it brings us closer to reality. It has also instilled in me a critical view of data, prompting me to question the results and graphs presented in research papers.
Wickham, in contrast, does not delve deeper into the philosophy of data collection, but he discusses the practical technical aspects of data collection. He discusses various tidyverse packages and how they can be used to tell a story using the example of animation. He uses a CSV file to to begin with and extracts the data into a data frame. Using this data frame, he plots data into charts over the years and then uses animation.
On a deeper level, this presentation made me wonder about the future ahead. Will we see code and text come together in this powerful manner? Thus, a lot can be done regarding data and creativity; authors will be able to express their ideas and opinions in a way never seen before, and coders will become authors, too. Therefore, I feel we are witnessing a revolution in terms of data.
In sum, Hadley Wickham’s video highlights the power of code in transforming data into visual representations. He focuses on the tidyverse package, which simplifies data manipulation and visualization in R. By demonstrating the Income vs. Life Expectancy graph, Wickham shows how data from a CSV file can be easily converted into R tables and then into dynamic, multi-year animations. He emphasizes tools like rmarkdown, knitr, and bookdown for integrating code and text in documents, merging coding and writing. This approach opens new possibilities for authors and coders to express data creatively, hinting at a revolutionary future in data communication.

title: Google Flu
text:
Big Data Analytics Pitfalls
Big data analytics holds significant promise, but it also presents key pitfalls. One major challenge is data quality and representativeness. Large datasets often contain missing or noisy data, leading to inaccurate predictions. Additionally, bias can creep in when data is collected from unrepresentative sources, skewing the insights drawn from it. Another pitfall is interpretability: complex models may produce outputs that are difficult to understand, making it hard to derive actionable insights. Lastly, over-reliance on algorithms can lead to overconfidence in results, especially when the data fails to capture nuances in real-world phenomena, such as shifting behaviors or unexpected outliers


Overfitting and Parametrization
Overfitting is a critical issue in data modeling, particularly when working with big data. It occurs when a model becomes overly complex, fitting not only the underlying trend in the data but also the noise. This reduces the model’s ability to generalize to new, unseen data, leading to poor performance in real-world applications. Over-parametrization, where too many parameters are used in a model, exacerbates this problem by increasing the risk of overfitting. This can lead to high accuracy on training data but poor accuracy on test data. Effective model validation techniques like cross-validation and penalization methods are necessary to mitigate overfitting​

title: Wickham Blogpost
text:
Income vs. life expectancy plot: Tidy data is a consistent way of mapping data, e.g., table, using CSV file to convert data, converting language into code
This enlightening video by the esteemed Hadley Wickham delves into the power of code in expressing data as graphics. He introduces the technologies of rmarkdown, knitr, reprex, bookdown, and pkgdown to showcase the potential of data visualization. Wickham’s expertise is evident in his ability to use simple language to convey the power of graphics.
He begins by posing a fundamental question: what does data visualization entail? He asserts that the tidyverse package, a comprehensive collection of packages designed for data manipulation and visualization, is a potent tool for data visualization. The presenter initiates the session by showcasing the Income vs Life expectancy graph, illustrating how R can effortlessly translate spoken language into code and facilitate the creation of intricate graphs.
Moreover, he meticulously guides the audience through the process of graph creation. He showcases the CSV file used to extract and store data in R tables. Subsequently, using these tables as a foundation, the presenter systematically plots the graphs for different years, providing a comprehensive understanding of the data visualization process.
He takes a sample graph of Income vs life expectancy and plots it in R with minimal differences. Then he does that for multiple years by scaling the data and then creating an animation of the data over time. This involves plotting the data for each year, then using a function to combine these plots into a single animation, providing a dynamic view of the data’s changes over time.
The animation looked very interesting. By demonstrating how simple-looking data in a CSV file was converted into rich animation in a matter of time using R, the presenter demonstrated the importance of technology and the power of the Tiderverse package. These packages can be used to write papers and books where code can be directly incorporated into documents. This is a powerful amalgamation of code and text never seen before.
On a deeper level, this presentation made me wonder about the future ahead. Will we see code and text come together in this powerful manner? Thus, a lot can be done regarding data and creativity; authors will be able to express their ideas and opinions in a way never seen before, and coders will become authors, too. Therefore, I feel we are witnessing a revolution in terms of data.
In sum, Hadley Wickham’s video highlights the power of code in transforming data into visual representations. He focuses on the tidyverse package, which simplifies data manipulation and visualization in R. By demonstrating the Income vs. Life Expectancy graph, Wickham shows how data from a CSV file can be easily converted into R tables and then into dynamic, multi-year animations. He emphasizes tools like rmarkdown, knitr, and bookdown for integrating code and text in documents, merging coding and writing. This approach opens new possibilities for authors and coders to express data creatively, hinting at a revolutionary future in data communication.
